Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Real-Time Learning Outcome Reporting
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project represents a new approach to transparently capture and report game-based learning (GBL) outcomes that will lead to an improved understanding of the benefits of GBL as an education technology for learning science. The K-12 educational market requires a consistent reporting system for learning outcomes in GBL products while sufficiently protecting student data. Given the important benefits that STEM-based GBL products can provide to allow for independent and enjoyable science education, teachers need improved reporting options to evaluate those benefits. The proposed research aims to solve both the reporting and benefits problem by creating a platform to report learning outcome data in a transferable format from multiple GBL products to a single dashboard. This will allow educators, administrators, parents and other stakeholders to build personalized learning plans and other support mechanisms required for individualized learning for every student using GBL and other education products. With better ways for the education community to measure, learn, control and understand the impact of their learning investments, GBL will be more widely adopted, and more high-quality STEM based GBL products will be needed, driving industry expansion and ultimately resulting in better learning experiences for all students. Higher adoption will lead to market growth, creating new jobs, higher quality products and drive student interest in science careers.

The proposed research will provide a software platform for reporting real-time learning outcomes in games using a standardized format to categorize and define the learners' actions. The platform addresses the issue of the lack of consistent, meaningful assessments for game-based learning (GBL) products and revolutionizes the way game-based learning data is analyzed. This new platform creates a base data format that aligns with national learning standards across various disciplines to create a robust, transparent and interoperable platform that can be used to build an industry-wide standardized system for tracking learning analytics in games and other educational products. Outcomes from multiple GBL products will be reported to a record store(s), giving stakeholders a complete view of student progress across multiple disciplines and products. Further, the platform provides protection for student data that does not currently exist in the GBL industry by allowing GBL data to report to a school-operated record store, instead of being stored on a game developer?s server. The platform created will provide a unified dashboard of standardized, interoperable, real-time data reporting and algorithm based analytics from games and other learning products. Project research focuses on working with stakeholders to define the schema for the standardized system and to develop a user-friendly reporting system to deliver the data to teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was the development of a new approach to transparently capture and report game-based learning  outcomes to create an industry standard for meaningful assessments for game-based learning (GBL). As a result of the project, a new standardized terminology for GBL telemetry (GBLxAPI) was developed to deliver reports to stakeholders in a consistent and predictable format.  Additionally, prototype software was created to report learning outcomes from multiple GBL products to a database store and to a prototype learning analytics platform, which was also created during the project. This prototype platform defines, categorizes and reports learners’ actions in GBL products in a consistent, predictable, transparent, and interoperable format that will allow stakeholders to: 1) assess the value of GBL products, 2) monitor student interaction with GBL products, and 3) evaluate student performance and intervene in real-time for personalized learning solutions.  Outcomes from multiple GBL products can be reported to a single location, giving stakeholders a complete view of student progress across multiple products from different vendors addressing various learning needs and academic disciplines.

The GBL industry currently suffers from a lack of standard reporting that is having an impact on adoption and innovation. Although educators are using games in significantly higher numbers than ever before, meaningful data on student performance in digital games is lacking (Pirani 2015). Millions of dollars of investment in GBL products are at risk of low adoptions because learning data tracking is not being addressed. The K-12 educational market requires a consistent reporting system for learning outcomes in GBL products while sufficiently protecting student data, allowing educators to take full advantage of the important benefits of STEM-based GBL products through assessment of student progress and achievement in near real-time, leading to immediate support and intervention for struggling students.

 

The research incorporated Experience API (xAPI), a public specification, as a base, extending the base data format into one that aligns with national learning standards across various disciplines. Our scope of research was to apply the xAPI framework to replace proprietary Learning Management System frameworks for games.  Research collected from teachers, students, GBL vendors and from relevant national standards led to the preliminary vocabulary and reporting standards for xAPI for GBL.  Technical goals focused on development of software to report learning outcomes from three (3) GBL products to a database store and the subsequent creation of a prototype learning analytics platform to display data for stakeholder review.  An in-depth investigation of student data privacy issues and best practices when reporting in-game data was also conducted. 

The research demonstrated that the prototype software can be implemented without impacting existing reporting or code bases, allowing for a transitional migration for developers, potentially accelerating future adoption.  An architecture for a commercial learning analytics platform has been designed. The initial GBLxAPI standard is currently being disseminated to industry stakeholders at gblxapi.org, public forums and private presentations.

The limited feature prototype developed during this project can be further expanded to build an industry-wide standardized system for tracking learning analytics in games and other educational products, giving stakeholders a complete view of student progress across multiple products that address various learning needs and academic disciplines. The standard data structure will allow innovative machine learning algorithms to identify patterns of learning that can be used for personalized learning plans not previously possible.  Additionally, disassociated standardized data can be placed into a research hub, leading to better evaluation of the effectiveness of GBL on student knowledge and skill development and improve research-based measures for creating and measuring student learning in games,

One key observation from the project has been the state of readiness of both educators and developers to adopt a standard for learning outcome reporting and a unified learning analytics dashboard. Users identified the standard and complementary reporting tool as a significant step towards wider implementation of GBL, noting that data and learning analytics are an essential part of incorporating more digital products into the classroom. Game developers were cautiously optimistic, seeing the standard as an innovative leap forward because the data is easily transportable and in a common format. Education administrators are eager to receive and analyze data with over 80% stating they needed data both to justify purchasing of GBL products and to merge with social demographic data, allowing educators to better identify the best educational tools for closing achievement gaps. As the growth of big data in the education industry continues to grow, this project provides greater opportunities for educators, administrators, parents and researchers to understand the learning data from digital products, leading to an improved understanding of the benefits of GBL as an education technology for learning science.  Ultimately, the standardized data generated by this platform could create new job opportunities for data scientists and analysts while simultaneously improving educational opportunities for underserved and struggling students.
